segments.text: Well, I'm working now.
I got it going.
Oh, good.
And so briefly, just for my tape recording, give us your full name so we have it on the tape.
Oh, sure.
Ronald Schleicher.
And you were telling my wife some fascinating things about how you work with physicians who are also writers.
Yeah.
Part of what we were talking about last night is

uh what they find and they've tested to find this is as students progress through medical school they become worse and worse at listening to patients at listening yes and and in fact at the oklahoma medical school but many of them do this when freshman medical students come in before they start classes they have them interview simulated patients and they record
their skills in obtaining information, and they do this every year, and every year they get worse.
The first two years are courses, the second two years are clinical work.
Through this clinical use, this third and fourth year, they did worse and worse.
And so we've designed this class, and now we're designing this project to try to teach doctors to listen better.
And the way to do it is to involve them in literature.
Wow.
And what precisely do you teach?
Why don't you tell me a little bit about what your background is?
Oh, my background is I have a degree in English in modern literature.
Wrote my thesis, my dissertation on Yates.
But I've done a million things.
I'm part of the Fund of English.
You can do whatever you want.
So this is not really a medical kind of a thing for you.
Well, it's become a medical thing because I've worked for six years.
Jerry and I have taught classes here on the campus and at the Health Science Center up in the city to medical students and pre-medical students.
In fact, Jerry even bought me a white coat.
That's great.
He told me if I were in the hospital, I'd be pounding our chest.
But it's wonderful.
I mean, these are the brightest and among the most motivated students you'll ever meet.
And they want to be good doctors.
And there's something about medical education.
We could talk about this a little bit.
Because I think we can specify what it is.
But there's something about medical education that teaches people
They don't have to interact with patients.
But to get back to something you said earlier, why were they getting worse and worse every year?
What was going on that they were regressing?
There are lots of speculations.
My educated sense is that—this is my office here—
I like this.
It's fine.
I'm very comfortable here.
It gets worse and worse because the nature of medical education is positive science.
And they're taught without having to interact with other people.
I mean, probably the course like this, which we've been teaching, is there's so much information
medical students need to learn.
So whose idea was it to bring an English professor into the medical school?
It was Jerry Veneta, the dean of the college.
Well, and I'll show you the—let me take off my jacket and I'll show you because it's on the computer.
Look at the cow, Greg.
My son took the cow.
What kind of old is he?
He's 20.
I mean, he's no child.
Well, that 20-year-old does the same kind of thing.
Well, I've got a polar bear in mine, which is kind of funny.
So we've probably got about 15 minutes, I would think, right?
Yeah.
She said she's going to come at quarter, too.
Okay.
Are they going to come here?
Yeah.
Oh, okay.
To pick you up.
In fact, I just made a presentation.
This is chapter two.
This is the small company up in Tulsa who are doing the technique.
This is the table of contents.
And this is the chapter we have here on the patient's story.
The story a patient brings to the physician is usually among the first and most important information that healthcare workers encounter.
These stories, narrated by the patient or, in special cases by others, present information organized in particular ways that call from particular times in which we're going to call ourselves again.
...the patient-physician relationship, and that help define the scope of healing and care in particular cases.
Here, I mean, there's some wonderful things here.
We've been here, although I won't go through the whole thing with a quote by William Carlin, as well as a great writer who was a physician.
Right.
And we've interviewed a mess of people, including Oliver Sacks,
But this is John Stone, who's a cardiologist at Emory, and we're contracted to have it done by October.
I mean, this is my favorite.
John came to Oklahoma City, and we've made him... Graduation at Emory University School of Medicine in 1982 with OEM is...
after Christopher Smart, so constructed about his cat, Geoffrey.
I just want to read the last part of this, but I want to underscore first that Gaudium Sagatur is an old medieval Latin drinking song, which many of you will have sung at graduation.
It means, therefore, let us rejoice.

story will come to you like hunger like thirst for you will know the answer like second nature like thirst for the patient will live and you will try to understand for you will be amazed the patient will not live and you will try to understand for you will be baffled for you will try to explain both either to the family for there will be laying on of hands and the letting go
was what death would always intend if it had the choice.
For the fever will drop, the bone remold along its lines of force, a speech will tremble itself.
So each chapter opens up with half a dozen people who calls.
We spoke to Robert Calls, and on the other hand,

our plan is now that we're good ways along we're going to get back in touch with him because we quote from his work with all of stories and one of the things even if we can't get him on camera i bet you i'm morally certain this beginning just talks about um uh patient stories and important and one of the ways this functions when we're done it'll run about eight or nine hours the whole thing is about narrative and storytelling literature and patience
In fact, one of the things we have, we have a search engine with different kinds of attention afforded by literature and narrative.
Reading this down here is part of what we're going to do is create what's called continuing medical education.
We need to take 150 hours every three years.
schools all over the country offer courses of one story or another.
Both Howard Medical College and Penn, who's publishing this, and Columbia, her name is Rita Sharon.

We hired this company, and we're just working closely with them.
So we're just finding images, and they paste them up, and we decide if we like them.
Is this something that you hope to ask them twice in medical schools?
Well, both.
Here's the problem.
Terry says to me, you'd like this.
When you go to medical school, you'll learn.
The students who we've had, I've taught for 25 years.
Can we get medical students to grudge this stuff when they have so much other stuff to learn?
And our medical school could say to second year students, this is what you have to do when you're not taking classes.
It's an AC.
It really is an exciting project.
One of the... So we have this.
We have... What we did is we... Later... We have a good search engine, but later we're going to... The later chapters that you're developing, you can go to a particular page.
I hired two English graduate students to work as our assistant on this to find images.

That he doesn't notice at this point.
He doesn't notice.

want to bring out of that poem with students or someone else teaching it would be to think perhaps about the way in which illness is almost never an isolated experience or individual experience that this is a shared experience in the poem between two people who are in love and that

the end of life i think which is visible in the poem uh is something that both people present in the poem must confront and and and so the one issue there i think that would be important the first this is a series of dvds and the first one they did is called red planet about mars in fact my a pal of mine bob markley did this
